repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: As suggested in #12139, I am replacing in this PR the error `E77: Too many file names` with a hint message `Maybe you meant to use :next` when the user tries to open multiple files as buffer using the Ex command `:edit *.js`.

comment_regular_data.body:
Hi. Could it be that this ticket's solution is really this simple? Or am I oversimplifying it? After checking the code, it seems to me that the only case to get the E77 message is to use wildcards in the name of the file you pass as argument to the Ex command `:edit` and therefore (if I am correct) a simple replacement of the error message is enough (no further implementation needed here).
Please let me know if this is correct.

I think that the solution is good.
Although, this might be an upstreaming candidate, and the modification can just be appending `maybe you meant to you :next` is good enough.

I'd really like @bfredl on this as this may be upstream-able.

To see if I understood; you mean to say that removing 'E77' from the message string would be good enough?
Should I perform such change?

I think what was meant was rather leaving the message as before and *adding* "maybe you meant..." to it:
```
E77: Too many file names (maybe you meant :next?)
```

Jetzt. Nice, I like that message better.
Thanks for the clarification.

Thinking about it, I'd probably be more explicit about the suggestion
```
E77: Too many file names (use :next instead of :edit with wildcards)
```

Hi @vigoux, @clason.

After some lint fixing commits, seems this is ready again for comments / feedback.
Could you please give me your opinions on whether there's still room for improvement here?
It looks pretty good. For me this can even be an upstream candidate.
If not too hard I would like to see a test, otherwise no disagreements from my end.
ping @brammool this would be a good ui enhancement for Vim as well, wouldn't it?

The "with wildcards" addition doesn't seem necessary.  I like the proposal "E77: Too many file names (maybe you meant :next?)".  The only thing the user needs is the hint that a different command would work.

I've also been thinking that when using ":edit" with a wildcard and there are several matches, to somehow edit the first one and keep the others available.  Unfortunately we can't just change the argument list without breaking users habits.  Perhaps an alternate ":nextmatch" command or ":usematchesforarglist" would work?  Or do more than a few people rely on ":e *.js" to fail when there are two or more matches?
Another idea is that after ":e *.js" failing there would be an easy way to switch to using :next instead.  Currently you have to do ":e<Up><Left><S-Left>...<BS>next<Enter>".  An ":imeantnext" command?  Or like the shell, use "!$" to refer to the previously used argument.  Then it would be ":n !$", easy enough.  And the error can be "E77: Too many file names(edit them with ":next !$" )

Tests are in place.
I created the new test in ./test/functional/ex_cmds/edit_wildcards_spec.lua
I don't know if that test should be placed under the mentioned path. If not, could you suggest me a more suitable path for it?
Also, I left the message of the error as suggested by @clason :
 * E77: Too many file names (use :next instead of :edit with wildcards)

I, as @brammool, think the message is a bit too verbose and I personally like more its shorter version.
So, let me know if you think this should also change.
And if not, then I hope this small and simple change will be merged.
:)

Hi.
Any feedback or any news on this one?

Hello @vigoux , @bfredl hope you're doing well and healthy (given the current times we are going through).
Any updates on this one? I don't mean to be pushy, just looking for feedback on whether it's good as it is or if it needs a change.
Greetings.

Hi, sorry for the delay, I pilled up a bit to much.
Could you make the message a little less verbose ?
Also, the recommended path for those kind of changes is to open a PR in `vim/vim` and that pull the patch there as a `vim-patch`, do you think you could do that as well ?

Hi.
So, I must create a patch of this change (with a less verbose message) an include that patch as a pull request in the vim/vim repository?
Sure I can do that!
Is there a deadline for that other PR?
What information do must I provide in that PR (since there is no ticket for this change in vim)?

> So, I must create a patch of this change (with a less verbose message) an include that patch as a pull request in the vim/vim repository?

If that's possible yes

> Is there a deadline for that other PR?

Absolutely not! Just do it when you feel you can, that'll be good. Deadlines do not exist here 

> What information do must I provide in that PR (since there is no ticket for this change in vim)?

I think that a link to this pr should be enough, as the issue is mentioned here.
Hi. Ok. I'll take care of it! :)

labels.description: Need comments/opinions from people familiar with this topic.
labels.name: needs:discussion

title: UX: ":edit *.js" should suggest :next (fixes #12139)
